segments.text: Make holiday gatherings more delicious at Whole Foods Market, whether you're the host or the guest who aims to impress.
Save now on baking essentials from 365 by Whole Foods Market.
Need some extra help?
Pick up crowd-pleasing flatbreads that are ready to heat, or build a lovely charcuterie board with sales on specialty cheeses and meats.
Holiday wines and beers are also on sale, starting at $7.99.
Host the perfect holiday party with Whole Foods Market.
Must be 21 plus, please drink responsibly.
Well hello there and welcome to Rising.
We are back at it with a fresh show on Friday.
And I'm very excited to be joined at the desk today by Inez Detman, senior policy analyst at the Independent Women's Forum.
Welcome Inez.
Thank you for having me back here.
You said having you back, you have a little bit of history with the show.
I hear you've been a panelist several times, obviously, with me.
And you also guest hosted a little back?
Yeah, I briefly filled in for solder when he was on vacation.
And I think at the end of that, I was like, you have a tough job.
So we'll see how this goes.
I'm glad you were willing to come back and take another bite at the Apple with us today.
We have a lot to get into, so let's get into it.
Ranking member on the House Oversight Committee, Democrat Jamie Raskin, is accusing Oversight Committee chair James Comer of quote,
misrepresenting his investigation into the Biden family and refusing to share information, including a copy of the Hunter Biden laptop hard drive.
This is according to Axios reports.
Raskin sent Comer a letter on Thursday accusing him of quote,
going on cable television to tout investigatory steps undertaken in secret or more disturbingly,
which may not have been taken at all, according to Axios.
The letter continued and has been nearly three months since he was soon for responsibility of the committee.
And in that time, I've grown increasingly alarmed by your efforts to shield information from committee Democrats,
including information collected as part of your investigation into members of the president's family.
Yeah, so what do you make of this one?
I mean, the claim, I guess, that Raskin is making here is that if they don't disclose some substance of what they are arguing about,
or what they're investigating, that they're able to stretch this implication that there is some real wrongdoing here,
which they haven't been able to substantively prove so far there's been no smoking gun,
and that they can coast on the implication that there was wrongdoing without ever having to prove it as long as the actual basis of the information remains private.
Is that a legitimate concern?
I mean, legitimate, but also, I think, old news.
I mean, we had an entire January 6th, you know, committee with no Republicans on it, right?
And that there were certainly leaks out of that and representations made in the media before evidence came before.
So I think this is actually politics as usual, and it's fine to lament that that's the case.

Obviously, everybody on the committee should have access to everything we should be able to trust that our members of Congress are not leaking stuff to the media selectively or not going on media to media shows to make false statements about what there is actually before them.
That being said, I do think that that's sort of water under the bridge at this point. This is politics as usual.

I mean, it is an interesting posture for Democrats to take to accuse the accusing folks of having a politicized, you know, investigation of someone in the midst of the Donald Trump indictment, which even many people who are left leading who are liberals are questioning the legal
efficiency of the claims that at least the ones that are coming out of New York.

And while I think there might have been a stronger argument that Republicans are politicizing this, and certainly Democrats have been arguing that Republicans have been politicizing the Hunter Biden laptop stories since time in memorial, I wondered, does it take on a different color against the back drop

of a district attorney who ran on, I'm going to get Trump getting Trump and having an unprecedented indictment of a not just a former president in the United States of America happening in the background, but someone who was leading candidate in the race for the Republican primary.
Right. They're domestic political opposition. Yeah. I mean, I think those are two different things, though, in part because Congress is supposed to be politicized, right?
To the extent that they are overly political and are not sharing with each other, like there is a remedy for that. We vote for that, right?

If the American people don't like the games that they're playing, if they become tired of the YouTube clips and hearings instead of substantive investigations, the American people do in fact have a remedy for that, right?

Whereas when the politicization gets into the rule of law, I think that's a much, much more dangerous precedent to break, and frankly, most Americans in this country, and I don't think this is exclusively on the right, and I think actually there's a bit of horseshoe effect here,

most Americans think, I think at this point, that the idea of equal justice under the law applied regardless to whether your politics are in favor or out of favor with the DOJ, with the current president, that seems like an idea that's very, very much under attack today.
Well, according to Axios, Comer has claimed he's talking to four different people associated with the quote, Biden influence peddling.
Raskin's letter also claims that Democratic committee staff asked Republicans about statements in the letter and were told no new witness information had actually been provided.
And according to the letter, the statements only refer to two individuals, Hunter Biden's business associate, Eric Schreren, as well as President Biden's former aide, Kathy Chang.
In response to the letter, Comer said, quote, multiple individuals have approached the oversight committee as whistleblowers with desire to share information confidentially.
It should be no surprise that whistleblowers do not trust.
Yeah, so I mean, this argument about whistleblowers, I wanted to protect their identity.
You know, credible, or as are the same people that we've been talking about this whole time.
Real true, whistleblowers in this, again, is just an excuse Republicans are using not to be more forthcoming about what they're actually investigating.
I mean, again, if you can flip this right back around and talk about the whistleblowers in the intelligence community who are coming to different congressional committees, right?
I think there's a lot of games behind the scenes in terms of leaking out identity.
And I think it's understandable that that reality is being accepted by players of both sides and therefore they're holding a lot of this information close to the vest, right?
We've seen this in past congressional investigations.
There was the skiff room, the famous skiff room, right?
To try to keep some of this from leaking.
But the problem is, again, this is politics.

I have much less of a problem with it happening in the venue that's appropriate to politics than I have this kind of leaking environment, whistleblower environment, for example, on the Supreme Court, right?
So I think there are places that are appropriate.
Politics has always been a knuckle sort of punching game.
I'm not surprised by that.
But what is shocking to me is moving that political venue into places like the courtroom, which is wholly inappropriate and unprecedented.
So I presume you're alluding to this pro-publicist story.
I believe we covered it on the show neither of us were yesterday, but covered it on the show yesterday.

I'm relating to Clarence Thomas receiving untold value out of these trips and gifts from a billionaire, one singular billionaire, and what influence that might have on the outcome of decisions in the Supreme Court.
It does really feel like everywhere you look, there's some kind of corruption going on.

I hear you making the distinction between a kind of partisanship in politics and a partisan versus a partisanship in the legal context, where there is at least an expectation that people are making decisions based on something other than their personal beliefs and partisanship.

But given that everywhere you look, it seems to be the case, at a certain point, is there a kind of diminishment of the political relevance of the ability for one party or another to capitalize on the perception that the other side is bad?
When it seems to be awash, especially for so many average Americans who are looking at all of this and saying, yeah, you're all corrupt.
What do you want me to do about it? Is this going to end up having me effectively just suppressing the vote?
Or is there going to be a reshuffling here, you think, of people feeling like one party or the other is more trustworthy?
And then that's a battle that Democrats and Republicans should be having right now.
The other guys, fraudulent, the other guys corrupt.
I actually think this was Donald Trump's greatest strength, in a sense, like that's a candidate, was the moment back in 2016 when he was like,
of course the whole thing is corrupt. I was there because I tried to ding him on the idea that he didn't pay a lot of taxes, that there was a lot of influence behind the scenes from donors.
He was like, of course there is. Of course I tried to influence people. Of course I tried not to pay my taxes. That's how the system works.

I alone can solve. We can debate that last part. But I do think that's the strongest argument he makes, and to the extent that this feeling that the game is rigged and the corruption is endemic to every one of our institutions,
to the extent that proliferates in the American people, and I think it rightly has.
Every one of our institutions basically has shown itself to be wholly politicized, corrupt, everything that you can name it.
I think that's a fair assessment. And then people start to look for candidates who are outsiders. So I think that helps Donald Trump.
I also think it helps some folks on the left. I think that the people have the hardest time defending themselves right now are people who are not acknowledging the deeper rot in the institutions.
Yeah, establishment politicians, beware in that case. All right, we'll have more rising for you right after this. Stick around.
House Judiciary Chair Jim Jordan has subpoenaed former New York assistant district attorney Mark Pomerance for his role in investigations of former President Donald Trump.
Pomerance declared Trump was, quote, guilty of numerous felony violations related to his tax returns, but resigned back in 2022 after D.A.
Alvin Bragg declined to move forward with related charges. Now Bragg responded to Jordan to Pina last night, writing, quote,
the House GOP continues to undermine an active investigation, an ongoing New York criminal case with an unprecedented campaign of harassment and intimidation.
These elected officials would better serve their constituents and their country by fulfilling their oath of office and doing their jobs in Congress.
Meanwhile, a new CNN report confirms that the judge overseeing Trump's prosecution made donations to progressive organizations and the Biden campaign during the 2020 election season.
Those donations, however, total just $35. Joining us now to weigh in on these developments is Emeritus Professor at Harvard Law School, an author of Get Trump.
Alan Dershwits, welcome back to Rising.
Well, thank you so much for having me. I appreciate it.

Professor Dershwhits, let's start by first just talking about the, the, the, the, the essential issue here, which people, even people who I think are really have a strong appetite for seeing Trump found guilty of some kind of felony.
They even themselves admit that there is a rather tenuous legal argument here to get
from the misdemeanor charges to a felony charge.
Do you see that as the biggest obstacle that D.A. Brad faces right now?
Well, first of all, the people who say that are wrong because there is no misdemeanor.
You know, in my book that you mentioned, get Trump, I go through each of the charges against
him in all four jurisdictions.
So let's start with New York, which is the weakest case.
Here's the misdemeanor that he brag lays out.
He says that when a man like Trump pays $130,000, plush money, to make sure that the allegation
of an adulterous affair is never made public, he must then immediately make it public in
his corporate disclosure forms.
Has anyone in history ever, ever paid hush money and then made it public?
Did Alexander Hamilton do that when he paid hush money to back in the 1800s?
It's never been done in the history of the country.
This is an invented misdemeanor.
I have challenged Bragg, show me a single case in history in your office or anywhere
else where anyone was charged for not disclosing the fact that he paid hush money to keep
an adulterous affair secret.
He can't do it.
It's totally made up.
So there's no misdemeanor to start with.
Then we go to the felony and you read the indictment that doesn't give you any hint
of what the felony is.
In the statement of facts, it suggests there are three grounds for the felony.
One to prevent disclosure of campaign contributions, which is really a stretch the federal government
campaign people did not prosecute.
Then there's this other one that the New York Times says is the smoking gun, the most serious
one.
The reason that he didn't list properly the hush money was because he might have two or
three years down the line wanted to cheat on his taxes.
That's what he basically says.
He says he put it in an entry there.
He wasn't sure.
Maybe the entry is legitimate.
Maybe it's not.
Maybe it was a reasonable expense.
We have no idea that Trump ever took it as a tax deduction.
He argues that he may have made this entry to help him evade $130,000 in taxes, which
would amount to an hour's wage for Donald Trump.
If and when he paid his taxes two or three years in the future, in 60 years of practicing
and teaching criminal law, I have never seen an indictment like this.
It's not that it's a thin indictment.
It's a non-existent indictment.
I went through every word of it and every word of the fact.
I could not find a single crime, misdemeanor or felony.
What about the other three outstanding potential indictments of Donald Trump?
How do you view those cases in comparison to what you call a thin indictment here?
Okay.
So in my book, Get Trump, I go through all four of them.
So this is the weakest by far.
Next you get to Fulton County.
One of the arguments is we haven't debt to rights.
There's a take in which he says, I need to find 13,000 votes.
But find has a dictionary definition.
It means they're there to be found.
They're not made up.
What he was saying is they may be uncounted votes as there are in many elections.
Go find them.
You can't prosecute somebody on that.
Oh, they'll say, but he really meant make them up.
But when he says something, you can't go beyond his words and say, that's what he
meant unless you have other evidence.
And I haven't seen it.
Well, just a push back on that point.
What would you say to folks who say, well, he said, he said, quote, I want you to do
what I want you to do is this.
I just want you to find a 11,780 vote.
The margin of defeat was 11,779 votes.
So specifically asking to find the number of votes that would close the gap of defeat
for him doesn't suggest to some people there are an unknown outstanding number of potential
and uncounted votes out there.
But specifically, I want you to look until you change the election result.
What do you say to folks who say that that is, that event is an intent to do something
other than simply make sure the election is accurate, but to come up with votes to ensure
that the election result changes?
It's perfectly right.
Perfectly okay to do that.
I was one of the lawyers in Bush versus Gore.
We were looking for 600 votes.
We were looking for it in Palm Beach County.
We were looking for another places in order to change the results of the election.
That's what election lawyers and that's what candidates do.
You look for votes to try to change the election result perfectly normal as long as you don't
make them up, as long as you don't manufacture them, it will concoct them.
And when you listen to the entire-
And when you listen to the entirety of that, Raphensberger call that went on for about
an hour as I understand it.
And you hear Raphensberger coming back and saying, well, I just really don't think there's
anything there.
Some people hear that and they see Trump or they interpret what Trump is doing as leaning
on him, trying to pressure him to come up with votes after he's already been clearly
told there's no evidence that there are any outstanding votes or that the result that
we've already had is inaccurate.
What do you say to folks who perceive that to be an effort and do an illegal election
interference?
Well, that's one of the reasons I don't vote for Trump.
I don't like what he did.
I disapprove of what he did, but the line between not liking and pressuring somebody
to try to bring about a result favorable to him, there's a big difference between not
liking it and it being a felony.
And it's just not a felony.
A person is allowed to push very hard election people and say, look, I think there are votes
out there.
You don't go, look hard.
He never said make them up.
He never said do anything fraudulent.
He said, fine.
And the dictionary has a meaning for fine.
It's there.
So I don't think there's a case there at all.
I've heard the entire conversation myself.
I don't approve of it.
Just as I don't approve the January 6 speech, I wish he hadn't made it.
But he said in that speech, I want you to go and protest peacefully and patriotically.
That brings him within the First Amendment.
Again, I go through all of these allegations in great detail in my book, Get Trump.
I just don't think there's anything in those two cases.
The strongest case, illegally, is Florida, where he did possess material that he shouldn't
have possessed, but so did Biden and so did Pence.
And I suspect so did many other presidents who left office and negligently took with them
classified material.
Now, they're trying to make an obstruction of justice case there.
That would be a reasonable case.
But the possession of classified material is going to be very hard because unless they
go after Biden, which they won't, and Pence, which they won't, the American public will
perceive it as a double standard of justice.
So I think he has a political, not a legal defense there.
He's also going to argue, of course, that he declassified.
And that's a question of fact.
And what no one knows is who is the burden of proof on that?
Does he have to prove he declassified or is the government approved beyond reasonable
doubt that he didn't declassify?
These are all very hard cases.
The one thing that's clear, his name was not Donald Trump, and he wasn't running for
election.
None of these investigations would be open.
These are all examples of getting the man first, targeting the man, and then rummaging
through the statute books and finding the crime.
The whole thesis of my book, Get Trump, is that that is not a proper way to proceed in
a prosecutorial manner.
The greatest attorney general in our history once said, any prosecutor can rummage through
the books, Robert Jackson said, and find something somewhere to pin on someone if they target
them and don't like them.
And that's what's going on here.
That's what happened when Laverente Berry, the head of the KGB, said to Stalin, show
me the man, and I'll find you the crime.
And this case has international implications.
The president of El Salvador lectured the United States recently in a tweet and said, you're
going after the man running for president against the incumbent, and you're lecturing
us about democracy.
You've lost all your standing to lecture any South of Central American countries about
democracy, mind your own house.
And this is not somebody who's a Trump supporter who said that.
It's the president of El Salvador.
So the idea that a district attorney can run in Manhattan on the campaign promise to get
Trump.
That's where I got the book title.
I didn't make it up.
It came from the campaigns of LaTisha James, who I like.
She's a very, very nice person.
And Bragg, who I'm told, is a very decent guy.
But these people campaigned on that pledge.
And when you can't pay her that pledge, you better take the promise.
That's a really worrying standard of politicization.
And this is obviously unprecedented, too, in diet, a former president, and especially
on charges that, as you just pointed out, at least out of this initial case out of Manhattan,
are certainly not very clear and not clear enough to, I think, justify breaking that
standard.
But I want to get your thoughts on this Jim Jordan subpoena, right?
So district attorney Mark Pomerantz, there's a subpoena out now.
Where do you think that this aspect is going to go and what is Jim Jordan looking for here?
Look, I don't like politicizing by either side.
The criminal justice system and the Republicans are doing it now back to the Democrats.
Of course, Pomerantz will resist the subpoena, but I think he'll probably lose.
And he probably will have to respond.
Congress does have a legitimate claim to looking into something that has had an impact
on our foreign policy.
If we can no longer hold ourselves out as the bastion of democracy, and if we are, you
mentioned going after a former president, that pales in comparison with going after a current
presidential candidate.
Think about what this looks like abroad.
You have a man, a Democrat, running for office on the promise that he will get the candidate
who's running against the head of the Democratic Party.
Many searches through the statute books can't find anything.
And he cobbles together a fake misdemeanor and a fake felony.
And he comes up with enough to convince 12 grand jurors to indict.
That surely impacts American foreign policy.
And Congress has the power to inquire into matters of foreign policy.
Should a local district attorney be allowed to run on that campaign?
I have to tell you, I do it legal ethics for what, 35 years in Harvard, I would immediately
pass an ethical prohibition on anybody running for prosecutor ever to campaign on the promise
to get somebody.
That's just un-American.
I think Congress.
Yeah.
It certainly feels like it would help his own case if he hadn't shown his hand quite so
much in the course of campaigning.
But before we go, I do want to come back to this point.
You've made about it being a kind of fake or meritless misdemeanor charge.
You opened by arguing that it kind of undermines the purpose of paying hush money to have
to report it.
And I think that is a logistical scenario that very few people will have to encounter.
It's a feature of campaign laws.
But it does seem to me, even though there's these statute of limitation questions, and
even though there's this question of whether or not you can fairly escalate the misdemeanor
into a felony using the federal election law hook given to the preemption issues, that
the underlying business records misdemeanor is in fact real, assuming that they could
prove it and assuming that they hadn't exceeded the statute of limitations.
Do you deny that there is a real claim there that Trump absolutely should not have when
he reimbursed Michael Cohen, not clarifying, not accounting for that accurately.
Wasn't a business records violation?
No, it wasn't because it's never been charged before.
You know, there was a great cartoon showing Donald Trump in a store tearing off the tag
on a mattress.
And Michael Cohen said, oh my God, we really got you now.
Yeah, I challenge, Greg, show me a single case in history, not only in your jurisdiction,
but anywhere where a person was actually prosecuted for not putting down in his corporate
records, the real reason why he paid the $130,000 to cover up an adulterous affair.
It has never ever happened.
It never will happen.
Why would anybody ever pay hush money?
And the John Edwards example.
Why would anybody have an undisclosed agreement?
The John Edwards example doesn't seem to remain to you.
No, no, no.
It was not acquitted.
Sure.
And it was a laughable case.
But that wasn't, that was a direct, you know, a direct payment.
And the question was, was that a campaign contribution?
It wasn't whether it was a fraudulent entry.
And you know, you can say it's a campaign contribution without explaining why it is.
But what Bragg is asking to be done is to be very specific.
Let's be here and clear about something else.
Donald Trump was extorted by Stormy Daniels.
Now, his lawyers will say, no, no, no, it wasn't an extortion.
We just said we would sue and make it public unless he paid $130,000.
If that's the case, then it's a legal expense.
Then he paid $130,000 to settle the lawsuit.
The Bragg can't have it both ways.
And if it was a legitimate payment, then it was a legal payment.
And if it wasn't, it was payment for extortion.
And I don't think anybody has ever, ever put down, oh, I paid extortion money.
It's just, it's just not the real world.
I went to Yale Law School.
I'm a real, I'm a legal realist.
I look at what has been happening in the past.
Again, my challenge is Bragg.
I sent it out three days ago, I haven't heard.
Show me a case.
He said to the public that business is bread and butter.
He does this all the time, including sexual cases.
Show me a single case where anybody in history has ever been prosecuted for not listing the
fact that he paid hush money in order to prevent the public from learning that he had an adulterous
affair with a marriage while he was married.
It's never happened so no.
I don't think the misdemeanor is a valid misdemeanor at all.
Well, thank you so much for joining us today, Professor Dershowitz.
Thank you so much.
Bob Marising, right after this.
The Department of Education announced a proposed change to Title IX yesterday to prohibit,
quote, categorical bans on transgender student athletes.
If adopted, it would be illegal for schools or universities to bar transgender student
athletes from participating on sports teams consistent with their gender identity just
because of who they are the department said.
According to ABC, while one size fits all provisions would be in violation of Title IX
should the rule pass, but schools would have the discretion to develop eligibility rules
for sports teams that could restrict transgender athletes ability to participate on a case
by case basis.
However, those restrictions would be reviewable by the DOE.
So this is definitely a rule that is telling states and schools what they can and can't
do.
A senior education department official said, quote, the proposed regulation would give
schools flexibility to identify their own important educational objectives.
They might include, for example, fairness and competition or preventing sports related
and injuries.
Twenty states have implemented laws prohibiting transgender students from, quote, participating
in sports consistent with their gender identities.
And according to the movement advancement project, a gender equality center, think, sorry, that's
according to that gender centered think tank.
So yes, of course, these state laws are preventing schools and people from doing what they want
to do.
All laws prohibit people from doing what they want to do.
The question is what the standard should be.
So is the government saying that there shouldn't be a blanket prohibition against saying no
trans people in sports of the identity of they identify as?
But you can potentially bar people on the basis of not having been on hormones for long
enough, not having surgically transitioned and other kinds of standards that bodies like
the Olympics have taken up over the years to try to create some semblance of equality
for this female athlete.
What do you make of it?
Well, the reason I added that about the clarity that this does actually restrict what states
and schools are able to do is because the department is kind of trying to have it both
ways here, right?
So that they want to say, OK, no blanket bans, no, for example, laws that fully prohibit
anyone born biologically male from participating in women's sports.
But in a case by case, racist basis, the department is going to review it.
So I think that regardless has a big chilling effect.
These are regulations, not laws.
So I mean, my view on this, I think it's quite simple.
I think that male and female bodies are incredibly different.
They're different in ways that are not adjustable by hormone levels and surgical intervention.
Those interventions don't change the truth of the differences between male and female
bodies.
And sports is a context where those differences are very important.
It might not matter, you know, sitting around the table talking to each other or who can
become a chemist.
But it matters very much how fast one can swim the 200 meter butterfly.
And so I think this is one more step that the department actually carved out sports because
it's such an obvious and clear issue about women's sports and males participating women's
sports.
So the department carved this issue out from their previous Title IX regulatory drops in
which, for example, they identified the term sex as including gender identity, which would
have sweeping consequences for sports except they kind of pushed it off until after the
election.
So this is right before the midterms when they included that.
So I think this is basically, that's why I added some stuff to this, is because this
was an attempt by the department to avoid the political consequences of their original
rulemaking back before the 2022 elections.
They're dropping it now, this carve out about sports that actually in some ways walks back
some of their language from the first batch of regulations where they do define sex as
fully including gender identity, which would essentially obliterate the ability of states
to distinguish between male and female under the law if those regulations are actually
become final, which they have not yet.
Yeah, it's interesting because the reaction from liberals in the broad left on this issue
is that this is a huge compromise that Biden has made after saying that there would be
no compromising with protecting the interests of trans people in the context of his primary
run.
He's now saying that there are people can, while you can't blanket ban, you can choose
to bar trans athletes from sports teams if there's some metric short of a ban, if there's
a blanket ban, if there's some hook, and again, we'll have to see what that hook ends up being,
but many liberals perceive that to be quite a significant betrayal.
I do think that this is, so that's just to say that I don't know about the politics of
this as you describe it.
I don't know that he's winning any, any plot it from any sector with this decision.
So if this is a political decision, it seems to be a very bad one.
I do think that the question of whether or not it is unfair to cis female athletes for
trans women to compete in sports is a more difficult one in the grand scheme of kind of
trans rights questions.
And that's precisely why this issue, which comes up relatively very infrequently, is
one that has national importance now as a national specter because I think a lot of
conservatives who are losing on some other issues, not having any kind of affirmative
plan about what to do about inflation, price gouging.
There's this huge report about the price of eggs actually being directly linked to price
gouging in that industry in particular, not having an affirmative plan in the wake of
Roe being overturned and the majorities of Americans not being happy with that decision.
To focus on some of these cultural issues where they do have an edge.
And so I'm conflicted because I do think it's a difficult issue.
I think it's an outsized political and national importance right now with the number of people
talking about it.
And I do think that it would be useful to be having conversations that the Olympics have
been having for a long time about what actually is fair.
How do you get to a point where it seems fair from a physical perspective to get a trans
woman to a place in terms of her hormone levels and estrogen levels and all those testosterone
levels where she isn't having an unfair competitive advantage against cis female athletes.
At the same time that question is complicated by the reality that so many athletes are
aberrant in their physicality in the first instance.
That's why they're elites.
That's why they're so successful with Michael Phelps having this wingspan that is inhuman
and extra ribs and all of this stuff.
And there are cis women who participate and have an edge because they have naturally
high testosterone levels.
So how to get around this is a really difficult question.
And I think it's a conversation that I think a lot of people would be more willing to have
more openly.
If it didn't seem like the political consequences of making sure that high school and college
sports were fair versus women to compete didn't seem to implicate some of these broader attacks
against trans rights and the hundreds of laws that have come down the pike just this year
that want to do things like prevent people from dressing and dragging and would make it
impossible to put on a classic Shakespeare production.
So I totally disagree with the characterization of those laws.
Those laws are to prevent children from going into sexualized drag shows.
I don't think there's any interpretation that would prevent like Romeo and Juliet style
cross-dressing.
But the Republicans just had to revise a bill.
I think it was in Tennessee because it accidentally would have prevented your hasty puddings production
at Harvard, your classic.
